content:
• Monday, May 18, 2015
  • AMCN

    AirMedia Group slips 3.8% after wider loss

    • After gaining 8.5% in market-hours trading today, AirMedia Group (NASDAQ:AMCN) is 3.8% lower after hours following a Q1 report where its net loss widened by 62% ($2.2M).
    • Revenues dropped 3.8% Y/Y and were down 9.7% sequentially. The company's still in the process of selling off its out-of-home advertising business for more focus on its Wi-Fi business.
    • Revenues by product line: Air Travel Media Network, $56M (down 3.2%); Gas Station Media Network, $2.25M (down 18.3%); Other Media, $2.57M (down 0.3%).
    • Conference call at 8 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:44 PM
  • TRQ

    Mongolia reaches deal to restart development of Oyu Tolgoi mine

    • Turquoise Hill Resources (NYSE:TRQ) +3.9% AH after announcing a settlement with Mongolia's government (I, II) in the two-year dispute over the expansion of the Oyu Tolgoi copper and gold mine, opening the door to ~$4B in new investment.
    • The focus now is expected to shift to finalizing financing for the project, as well as a feasibility study and the securing of all necessary permits for development of the underground to begin.
    • TRQ owns 66% of Oyu Tolgoi, and Rio Tinto (NYSE:RIO) controls the project through its 51% stake in TRQ; the Mongolian government owns the remaining 34%.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:08 PM | 8 Comments
  • GSAT

    Globalstar tumbles at close; presents at conference Wednesday

    • Globalstar (NYSEMKT:GSAT) slid into the close today, falling to -5.5% in the last half-hour on no visible news.
    • The company is presenting Wednesday morning at the J.P. Morgan Global Technology, Media and Telecom Conference -- but isn't hinting at the content and won't have prepared material to distribute.
    • This week Globalstar launched the SmartOne C, its latest model of one-way asset trackers -- a roughly 3-inch square device with accelerometer that can alert owners to unexpected motion (like theft) and provide connectivity well beyond cellular coverage. CEO Jay Monroe pitches it as an Internet-of-Things play.
    • Shares are down 24% over the past month; they had gained 21% in the two weeks following a demo of its TLPS technology at the FCC.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:05 PM | 2 Comments
  • EOX

    Emerald Oil to launch $150M offering

    • Emerald Oil (NYSEMKT:EOX) -16.6% AH after announcing a public offering totaling $150M in common stock, with an underwriters option to purchase additional shares worth $22.5M.
    • EOX says it plans to use the proceeds to fund the acquisition of Delaware Basin assets announced last week, to repay outstanding credit facility borrowings and for general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:50 PM | 41 Comments
  • SABR

    Sabre selling 22M shares on behalf of holders; shares -2.3%

    • P-E firms TPG and Silver Lake will be selling 22M Sabre (NASDAQ:SABR) shares (~8% of outstanding shares) through a public offering.
    • Sabre has fallen to $25.44 AH. Shares had risen 29% YTD going into today.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:28 PM
  • BIOL

    Biolase up 7.4% on CEO change

    • Biolase (NASDAQ:BIOL) has risen to $2.18 AH after announcing Harold Flynn, formerly the president of dental implant/prosthetics maker Zimmer Dental, is its new CEO, replacing Jeff Nugent.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:46 PM | 2 Comments
  • TTWO

    Take-Two up 7.3% after earnings; details pipeline, Asia plans

    • Take-Two Interactive (NASDAQ:TTWO) is up 7.3% after hours following its fiscal Q4 and year-end results, where some revenue deferrals made for a heavy GAAP loss but boosted strong guidance for Q1. The company's forecast for the coming year was also to the downside of expectations.
    • Elaborating on forecasting on its earnings call, CEO Strauss Zelnick noted that despite a slow pipeline from Rockstar Games, they're hard at work on a number of upcoming titles: "Rockstar today is different from the Rockstar of a few years ago," he said noting that the release of Grand Theft Auto Online has changed its world as "a living, breathing entity" that generates revenue and profits on an ongoing basis.
    • The company increased its buyback authorization to 10M shares; on the call, management noted that buybacks aren't anticipated in its expectations for a fiscal 2016 EPS of $0.75-$1.00.
    • Regarding Asia Pacific, Zelnick said it's a "very significant area of focus for us," pointing to NBA 2K's monthly revenues/profits. "Now we feel a little more confident about financial risk because we have a good deal of experience in the region ... I think in the Chinese market, it's likely that we -- and our competitors -- will have local partners. The Chinese government wants us to work with strong local partners, and Tencent and others are proving to be exceedingly strong partners for us."
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: MOMO +10.7%. TTWO +6.5%. LAKE +3.3%. FOX +1.5%. SGYP +1.3%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: URBN -16.5%. LINE -4.9%. ACHN -3.9%. LNCO -2.8%. HDS -2.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 8 Comments
  • YGE

    Yingli falls 36% on solvency fears

    • "Facts and circumstances including recurring losses, negative working capital, net cash outflows, and uncertainties as to the repayment of debts raise substantial doubt about our ability to continue as a going concern," says Yingli (NYSE:YGE) in its 2014 annual report (filed after the close last Friday). "Our lack of cash resources and our potential inability to continue as a going concern may materially and adversely affect the price of our ADSs and our ability to raise new capital or continue our operations."
    • The remarks sparked fresh solvency fears, and led shares to fall 12.4% to $1.49 in regular trading. They've seen bigger losses AH, dropping 26.9% to $1.09 and yielding a 36% decline for the whole day. Yingli had  $172.3M in cash, $214.7M in restricted cash, $1.57B in short-term borrowings, $276.1M in medium-term notes, and $460.7M in long-term debt at the end of Q4.
    • SA author Casual Analyst offered a bearish take on Yingli's disclosure yesterday. "Given the weak situation that the Company is already in, Yingli, in its current form, seems to have entered a death spiral. The Company may survive for the benefits of debt holders and controlling shareholders, but the most common stockholders and ADS holders will likely be wiped out soon."
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM | 3 Comments
  • ROAN

    Linn Energy to launch 16M-unit offering

    • Linn Energy (LINE) -5.3% AH after announcing a public offering of 16M common units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 2.4M units.
    • LINE says it plans to use the proceeds to repay debt under its credit facility, whose debt was incurred primarily to fund the open market repurchases of LINE and Berry's senior notes.
    • LNCO -3.1% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM | 54 Comments
  • GIGA

    Giga-tronics +19.7%; $10M order announced with earnings

    • Along wit its FQ4 results, Giga-tronics (OTC:GIGA) announces it has "finalized a $10.0 million multi-year production order of high performance YIG filters for a major aerospace company."
    • Shipments are expected to start in Aug. 2016, and continue through early 2019. The component order follows a $6.5M engineering order (received in June 2014) for the development of the filters.
    • Shares have soared to $2.55 AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:49 PM
  • ARP

    Atlas Resource to buy Oklahoma nat gas assets, launch 6.5M-share offering

    • Atlas Resource Partners (NYSE:ARP) -5.3% AH after agreeing to acquire natural gas producing properties in the Arkoma Basin in eastern Oklahoma from its parent company, Atlas Energy (OTC:ATLS), for $35.5M.
    • The Arkoma assets consist of ~41B cf of mature, low-decline natural gas reserves which produce ~11M cf/day from more than 550 active wells.
    • ATLS expects to use the proceeds from the sale to pay down a portion of its existing term loan, which has an outstanding balance of $104M.
    • To help fund the deal, ARP plans to launch a public offering of 6.5M common units, which includes an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 975K units.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:38 PM | 13 Comments
  • A

    Agilent -3.4% after FQ2 miss; FY15 EPS guidance maintained

    • Though it missed FQ2 estimates, Agilent (NYSE:A) is maintaining FY15 (ends Oct. '15) EPS guidance of $1.67-$1.73 (consensus is at $1.69). Revenue guidance has been cut by $10M to $4.05B-$4.11B (consensus is at $4.07B).
    • FQ3 guidance is for revenue of $995M-$1.015B and EPS of $0.38-$0.42 vs. a consensus of $1.00B and $0.42.
    • Orders: FQ2 orders totaled $1.04B, +1% Y/Y and above revenue of $963M (1.08 book-to-bill). Life Sciences/Applied Markets (LSAG) orders +4% to $506M; Diagnostics/Genomics +6% to $168M; CrossLab Group (lab testing equipment) +5% to $365M.
    • Financials: GAAP costs/services fell 4% Y/Y to $856M (compares with a 3% revenue decline). Cost of products/services -4% to $483M; SG&A spend -4% to $292M; R&D -7% to $81M. $162M was spent on buybacks. Agilent ended FQ2 with $2.20B in cash and $1.66B in long-term debt.
    • A strong dollar had a 7% impact on revenue growth. Agilent notes LSAG was unable to convert all of its FQ2 order strength into revenue during the quarter.
    • Shares have fallen to $41.20 AH.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM
  • TTWO

    Take-Two misses revenues after heavy deferrals

    • Take-Two Interactive (NASDAQ:TTWO) spent the last 10 minutes sinking into the close to finish -2%, just before an earnings release for its fiscal Q4 showing a miss on revenues despite 83% growth.
    • GAAP results showed a net loss of $2.99/share, reflecting some net revenue and cost of goods deferrals. On a non-GAAP basis, EPS was $0.49 vs. an expected $0.28 and against last year's $0.21.
    • Revenue from digitally delivered content was up 66% Y/Y, to $202.5M. Biggest contributors to revenue for Q4: Grand Theft Auto V (freshly released for PC), Grand Theft Auto Online, Evolve, NBA 2K15 and Borderlands: The Handsome Collection.
    • It's increased its buyback authorization up to an aggregate 10M shares.
    • The firm's guiding high for its fiscal Q1, for non-GAAP revenues of $325M-$350M vs. $207M expected, and for EPS of $0.25-$0.35 vs. an expected -$0.01. For fiscal 2016, the company expects non-GAAP net revenue of $1.3B-$1.4B, lower than expected $1.82B, and EPS of $0.75-$1.00 vs. an expected $1.87.
    • Conference call at 4:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 6 Comments
  • BRG

    Bluerock Residential lower by 2% on secondary

    • Bluerock Residential Growth (NYSEMKT:BRG) files to sell 3.85M shares with an underwriter greenshoe for another 575.5K shares.
    • The stock's lower by 2% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • URBN

    Urban Outfitters -12% after earnings disappoint

    • Urban Outfitters (NASDAQ:URBN) reports comparable retail segment sales rose 4% in Q1.
    • Comp sales growth by brand: Free People +17%, Urban Outfitters +5%, Anthropologie Group +1%.
    • Wholesale segment sales were up 18%.
    • Gross profit rate -141 bps to 33.3%.
    • SG&A expense rate flat at 26.1%.
    • Operating income rate -150 bps to 7.2%
    • Total inventory +14% Y/Y to $398M.
    • URBN -12.1% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • SCHN

    Schnitzer Steel upgraded at KeyBanc, which sees stabilizing scrap industry

    • Schnitzer Steel (SCHN +9.5%) is upgraded to Overweight from Sector Weight with a $25 price target at KeyBanc, which cites a potential bottoming in U.S. scrap industry fundamentals as well as compelling valuation.
    • The firm says recent analysis suggests a broader based U.S. metals recycling industry rationalization, which it believes could potentially allay feedstock and input costs for recyclers as competition for material eases.
    • Cheap iron ore and Chinese steel overproduction threatens SCHN's long-term model, though stabilizing commodity prices, an improving European macro environment and a weaker U.S. dollar should help in the short term, JeyBanc says.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM | 2 Comments
  • ERN

    Erin Energy tops 7K bbl/day of oil from Nigeria Oyo-8 well

    • Erin Energy (ERN +14.7%) is surging following news that its 100%-owned Oyo-8 well offshore Nigeria has exceeded expectations and is producing at a stabilized rate of 7,080 bbl/day of oil, and is engaged in drilling and completion operations on the Oyo-7 development well with first oil production expected in a few weeks.
    • Also, ERN says it has completed site survey of three of its top Miocene exploration prospects offshore Nigeria; its top four prospects there have a combined 2.4B barrels of recoverable P50 prospective resources.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM | 4 Comments
  • RIG

    Goldman: Pain ahead for Tranoscean, Diamond Offshore, Atwood Oceanics

    • The Goldman Sachs energy team is as gloomy as ever on offshore drillers such as Sell-rated Transocean (RIG -3%) and Diamond Offshore (DO +0.9%), as well as downgraded Atwood Oceanics (ATW -3.2%), believing that 2017 will be "a particularly painful year."
    • The industry is retiring floating rigs, but that will not solve the problem without rising demand, Goldman says, expecting demand instead will fall an additional 8% by 2017, which will keep utilization at 77% and meaning significant further idling of floating rigs and sizable rate pressure on deepwater rigs.
    • Goldman says although ATW remains the "best-in-class” offshore driller and is somewhat cushioned in 2016-17 from the weak macro environment owing to contract backlog, the company faces significant re-contracting risk in 2017, which is "becoming hard to ignore."
    • Earlier: BP, Statoil, Chevron cut to Sell at Goldman Sachs
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM | 19 Comments
  • CEI

    Lucas Energy-Victory Energy merger deal is dead

    • A deal that would have provided a financial lifeline to cash-strapped Lucas Energy (LEI -10.1%) is terminated after proposed merger partner Victory Energy (OTCQB:VYEY -24.1%) backs out of the agreement.
    • Victory also says it will not extend further credit to Lucas.
    • The companies say they are working to finalize the terms of a mutual settlement and release agreement.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM
  • T

    AT&T targets connected cars for exclusive mobile content

    • AT&T (T +1.8%) is planning exclusive mobile content for connected cars and has eight automaker partners to work with on the initiative.
    • The company is trying to offer free or paid games and videos exclusively to the cars in an effort to sell more data, now that the market is growing more saturated with mobile phone users.
    • Partners include General Motors, Audi, and Ford. AT&T's looking at different business models to make the plan happen, including different revenue shares and an advertising infrastructure.
    • "A lot of (content and offers) can be targeted to the make and models of the vehicles," says AT&T's emerging-devices chief Chris Penrose.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM | 8 Comments
  • JASO

    JA Solar -4.6% after mixed results; full-year guidance maintained

    • JA Solar (NASDAQ:JASO) has fallen below $10 after missing Q1 revenue estimates. A better-than-expected gross margin (+60 bps Q/Q and -60 bps Y/Y to 16.1%) allowed EPS to beat; JA attributes the margin strength to lower materials costs and strong sales to high-ASP Japan.
    • Q1 cell/module shipments totaled 681.5MW, -28.5% Q/Q (seasonality) and +6.8% Y/Y, and in-line with guidance of 650MW-700MW. Shipments are expected to total 680MW-720MW in Q2; full-year guidance of 3.6GW-4GW (200MW for downstream projects) is maintained, with JA forecasting Chinese and North American demand will improve in 2H15.
    • Business performance: Module shipments +50.5% Y/Y to 584.1MW; cell shipments -61.1% to 97.4MW. China accounted for 21.4% of Q1 shipments, other Asia-Pac markets 53.9%, Europe 22.6%, the Americas 1%, and other markets 1.1%.
    • Financials: Operating expenses were 9.9% of revenue, up from 9.3% in Q4 and 9.7% in Q1 2014. JA ended Q1 with $306.2M in cash, $325.2M in short-term borrowings, and $365.8M in long-term borrowings.
    • Q1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM | 2 Comments
  • CHL

    Chinese wireless firms trading lower, slashing data rates

    • After closing lower in Hong Kong, China's big three wireless carriers are down in U.S. trading, giving back Friday gains after saying they'd cut data prices and boost speeds in an effort that could push migration to 4G.
    • In the U.S., China Mobile (NYSE:CHL) is down 4.1%; China Telecom (NYSE:CHA) is down 4.1% and China Unicom (NYSE:CHU) down 3.2%.
    • The state-owned firms have gotten a push from Premier Li Keqiang to expand Internet access. Leader China Mobile will cut mobile data prices by at least 35% this year; China Unicom plans cuts of 20% or more per megabyte, and China Telecom is looking at average cuts of 30%/megabyte.
    • The move means a change in short-term revenue but could raise profits depending on the migration rate to more lucrative 4G accounts and usage.
    • Previously: China mobile infrastructure spending jumped 51% in 2014 (Apr. 21 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM
  • DDD

    3D Systems +4.9%; Navy deal announced

    • After making fresh multi-year lows on Friday following news of CFO Ted Hull is leaving to "meet company needs and to pursue his personal interests," 3D Systems (NYSE:DDD) is rebounding today.
    • The gains come after 3D announced an R&D partnership with the U.S. Navy to "jointly develop and evaluate 3D printing technology and materials for military uses, including helping the Navy fulfill a number of strategic initiatives." 3D's metal printers and polymer materials will be leveraged.
    • Profit-taking from shorts could be helping out today: 37.2M shares (35% of the float) were shorted as of April 30, not far removed from a 52-week high of 38.6M.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:36 PM | 8 Comments
  • DSKY

    iDreamSky +10%; Rosenblatt reiterates Buy, company issues PR

    • Rosenblatt Securities has reiterated its Buy rating and $11 target for iDreamSky (NASDAQ:DSKY) in a new bullish note. iDreamSky has decided to issue a PR to help share the news.
    • Rosenblatt forecasts a strong Q1 report later this month, aided by Chinese New Year promos for Ninja Fruit, Temple Run, and other games. The firm's Q2 estimates have been slightly cut due to China Mobile's temporary suspension of billing systems in several provinces, but it thinks new games will help offset. "We believe China Mobile cracking down on illegal games will be positive for DSKY over the long-run."
    • Rosenblatt's $11 target is respectively equal to 12x and 7x estimated 2015 and 2016 EPS of $0.94 and $1.57.
    • Shares remain down 46% YTD; they sold off hard in January, and plunged in March due to a Q4 warning and soft Q1 guidance.
    • Last week: SA author questions iDreamSky's accounting
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM | 6 Comments
  • LTBR

    Lightbridge says four large utilities ask NRC to review its metallic fuel design

    • Lightbridge (LTBR +51.8%) soars more than 50% after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission disclosed that four U.S. electric utility companies representing nearly 50% of U.S. nuclear generation have formally asked the NRC to prepare to review LTBR's patented metallic fuel design, citing opportunities for the fuel product to "significantly improve safety and fuel cycle economics" of nuclear power plants.
    • The joint letter was being submitted in advance of an expected application to the NRC in 2017 for use of LTBR's fuel lead test assemblies in an operating U.S. pressurized water reactor as early as 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM | 3 Comments
  • SWKS

    Chip stocks rally following Intel/Altera report, Chinese tariff cuts

    • Many chip stocks are turning in healthy gains amid a 0.7% gain for the Nasdaq after the NY Post reported Altera (up 6.2%) has resumed buyout talks with Intel.
    • Also possibly helping: China's big-3 carriers have announced major data tariff cuts. Brean has argued the cuts are a positive for RF chipmakers Skyworks (SWKS +5.7%), Qorvo (QRVO +4.2%), and Avago (AVGO +1.9%); the companies benefit from rising 4G phone sales.
    • Aside from the aforementioned companies, today's gainers include Synaptics (SYNA +4.8%), Himax (HIMX +2.3%), and Silicon Motion (SIMO +2.3%), each of whom also has Chinese mobile exposure. Other winners include Atmel (ATML +3.7%), Microsemi (MSCC +2.6%), InPhi (IPHI +2%), Intersil (ISIL +2.5%), Silicon Labs (SLAB +2.5%), IDT (IDTI +2.3%), and MaxLinear (MXL +3.5%).
    • Chip ETFs: SOXX, SMH, XSD, PSI, SOXL, USD, SOXS, SSG
     
     
     
     
    | 2:10 PM | 1 Comment
  • GTXI

    GTx continues cancer therapy development-stoked rally

    • Micro cap GTx (GTXI +12.7%) moves up again today on more than a 10x surge in volume. Shares have almost doubled from the intermediate low of $0.65 on April 10.
    • The party kicked into high gear on May 8 when the company reported Q1 results and updated investors on its progress with selective androgen receptor degrader (SARD) compounds and the pending start of two Phase 2 trials assessing its lead product candidate, enobosarm, a selective androgen receptor modulator or SARM, in certain types of breast cancer. The first trial, assessing enobosarm in up to 55 patients with androgen receptor (AR)-positive triple negative breast cancer, will initiate enrollment next month. The second, in up to 118 patients with AR+/Estrogen receptor(ER)-positive advanced breast cancer, will commence shortly thereafter.
    • The company announced a license deal with the University of Tennessee Research Foundation for SARD compounds that may be capable of degrading multiple forms of AR. It intends to initially target development for those patients with progressive castration-resistant prostate cancer who do not respond or are resistant to currently approved therapies. The first preclinical work will begin later this year.
    • AR and ER are hormones that stoke certain cancers. Currently approved selective estrogen receptor modulators or SERMs are: tamoxifen, raloxifene (Eli Lilly's Evista) and toremifene (ProStrakan's Fareston). There is a significant unmet need for a SARD-type approach in triple negative breast cancer since chemo is the only approved therapy.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM | 3 Comments
  • WBAI

    500.com down 8% ahead of earnings

    • 500.com (NYSE:WBAI) is off sharply ahead of tomorrow morning's Q1 report. 1.5M shares have been traded vs. a 3-month daily average of 2.2M.
    • The Chinese online sports lottery provider cratered in February in response to provincial lottery suspensions, but recovered most of its losses in April after a set of national mandates arrived.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:46 PM | 1 Comment
  • PERY

    Multi-year highs for Perry Ellis

    • Shares of Perry Ellis (PERY +4.3%) are at their highest level in four years as last week's strong guidance from the company continues to draw in investors.
    • During the earnings call last week, global growth was a major topic with Perry Ellis execs.
    • They noted some global categories saw double-digit growth rates in Q1 and widened out margins.
    • Earnings call transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 1:45 PM
  • WIN

    Windstream, CS&L lower as Goldman updates coverage

    • Windstream Holdings (NASDAQ:WIN) is off 2.6% now, following an update from Goldman Sachs analysts who lowered the price target on the shares to $7.50, from $7.75, after pricing in Windstream's 19.6% stake in its REIT spinoff Communications Sales & Leasing (CSAL).
    • The analysts figured the target using a blend of Windstream's 7.5% dividend yield and a look at estimated 2016 enterprise value-to-EBITDA.
    • Meantime, CSAL is down 1.8%. Goldman launched coverage on the REIT at Neutral, with a $27 price target. Shares are trading currently at $27.02.
    • Windstream shares are trading at $8.38.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:38 PM | 11 Comments
  • SPLK

    Splunk makes CTO change; shares -4.6% (updated)

    • Splunk (NASDAQ:SPLK) has named Snehal Antani, formerly the CIO of multiple GE Capital units and before that an IBM exec, its new CTO.
    • No word on the status of former CTO Todd Papaioannou, who was appointed in 2013 following the resignation of his predecessor, Erik Swan. For now, Papaioannou's LinkedIn page still lists him as Splunk's CTO.
    • Antani will work with products SVP Guido Schroeder and strategy chief Stephen Sorkin to "direct the long-term vision for Splunk technology across Splunk's rapidly expanding cloud, mobile, on-premises and hybrid offerings." He'll report to chairman/CEO Godfrey Sullivan.
    • Splunk has sold off towards $67 following the news. Shares had made a new 2015 high of $70.97 on Friday. FQ1 results arrive on May 28.
    • Update: Cantor is defending Splunk following the news. The firm considers the CTO change "an upgrade," and expects "stronger trends as the year progresses."
    • Update 2: A Splunk spokeswoman tells Seeking Alpha Papaioannou is no longer with the company.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: LTBR +51%. GBR +31%. OSUR +21%. PFNX +17%. GTXI +16%. SGYP +13%. BOSC +11%. UWN +13%. TCX +12%. VTNR +12%.
    • Losers: OTC:SOFO -17%. OTCPK:FSAM -15%. DXM -13%. CHKR -12%. YUMA -11%. MNGA -11%. RGSE -10%. SDT -10%. NVIV -10%. ICLD -9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM | 11 Comments
  • XLNX

    Xilinx up after new Intel/Altera report; Avago a potential suitor

    • Xilinx (XLNX +1.3%) is higher after the NY Post reported Intel and Xilinx FPGA archrival Altera have resumed buyout talks. Shares jumped in March after the first Intel/Altera report arrived.
    • Last week, Reuters reported Avago (AVGO +1.3%) has reached out to Xilinx, analog/mixed-signal chipmaker Maxim (MXIM +0.6%), and Japanese microcontroller/analog chipmaker Renesas (OTCPK:RNECF) about potential deals. Sources also state Avago has talked with P-E firm Silver Lake about partnering on a deal.
    • Avago has acquired LSI, PLX Technology, and Emulex over the last 2 years, and was previously reported to have bid for Freescale before the company agreed to merge with NXP. The company is one of many chipmakers taking part in a consolidation wave driven by both cost and product synergies.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:35 PM
  • FCAU

    Big bets laid out on Fiat Chrysler Automobiles

    • There's a high level of options trading being reported on Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCAU +0.4%).
    • The volume spike could be tied to market chatter on Apple taking a stake.
    • Big Three scorecard: FCAU is +34% YTD vs. Ford -0.1% and GM +0.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM | 2 Comments
  • PDCE

    PDCE Energy earns Buy rating at Goldman as production beats peers

    • PDC Energy (PDCE +4.8%) is initiated with a Buy rating and $77 price target at Goldman Sachs, which cites strengths lie in PDCE's low cost structure and strong energy base.
    • Goldman expects PDCE's oil production to surpass the average level achieved by its peer group, anticipating 41% growth in Q2-Q4 2015 and a further 31% in 2016 vs. the respective 1% and 13% average it sees for peers.
    • PDCE shares have outperformed driven by improved oil equity sentiment, but the firm "see(s) room for additional outperformance as PDCE approaches an inflection in growth/resource in H2 2015 after sub-par execution in 2014."
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 1 Comment
  • BP

    BP, Statoil, Chevron cut to Sell at Goldman Sachs

    • Goldman Sachs says its “lower for longer” oil price forecast would put significant pressure on integrated oil and gas companies such as BP (BP -0.8%)and Statoil (STO -2.7%), prompting the firm to downgrade its sector outlook to Cautious from Neutral and both energy giants to Sell from Neutral, citing long-term dividend risk for BP and cash-flow pressure on STO.
    • The firm also downgrades Chevron (CVX -1%) to Sell from Neutral with a $99 price target, down from $111, saying CVX is burning through free cash flow, which should limit dividend growth in the coming quarters, and pointing risk to 2017 production guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:49 AM | 33 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras turns lower after early gains, Goldman downgrades to Sell

    • Petrobras (PBR -1.9%) fails to hold opening gains that followed its surprising Q1 earnings beat, as Brazilian stocks turn lower following a central bank poll that showed analysts are forecasting the worst economic contraction in the country since 1990.
    • Economists covering Brazil now foresee GDP contracting 1.2% and inflation rising to 8.3%; PBR's Q1 earnings "were a relief to investors [but] there’s still a lot of uncertainty regarding the deceleration of the economy," says the chief economist at brokerage firm TOV Corretora.
    • Goldman Sachs is downgrading the stock to Sell from Neutral with a new $5.10 target price, noting shares have outperformed other Latin American energy companies by ~10% since late January.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM | 20 Comments

  • TOT

    French regulator OKs conditional sale of UGI's purchase of Total LPG unit

    • France's antitrust agency authorizes the sale of Total's (TOT -1.8%) liquefied petroleum gas unit in France to UGI Corp. (UGI -0.1%) provided the buyer sells some storage facilities and amends supply contracts with TOT.
    • The local anti-trust agency says the merger without conditions would have given UGI's local unit Antargaz too strong a position in the market.
    • Total and UGI last July announced the sale of the unit for €400M-€450M.

  • GPRO

    GoPro higher on Oppenheimer upgrade

    • Believing near-term headwinds have abated and rising sales within underpenetrated international market will provide a lift, Oppenheimer's Andrew Uerkwitz has upgraded GoPro (GPRO +1.9%) to Perform.
    • Nonetheless, Uerkwitz says his "longer-term negative bias" for the company is "stronger than ever." He thinks the "convenience of mobile handsets will trump standalone recording devices in the long-term" (ed: users needing a camera mount to record will arguably get less of a convenience benefit), and thinks GoPro's cameras are "seriously lagging in terms of hardware/software user interface, services, and technological capabilities."
    • Uerkwitz launched coverage on GoPro at Underperform last October, and has reiterated his bear case many times.

  • DRRX

    Durect up 11% premarket on successful Phase 1 safety study of DUR-928

    • Durect (NASDAQ:DRRX) is up 11% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement of results from a multiple-ascending dose Phase 1 study of DUR-928, a small molecule drug candidate that modulates the activity of various nuclear receptors involved in liver homeostasis (stable function). It is under development for the potential treatment of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
    • The 20-subject single-site, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled multiple-ascending-dose study assessed the safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetics of DUR-928, orally administered once daily for five consecutive days in healthy volunteers. DUR-928 was well tolerated and no severe or serious drug-related adverse events were observed. Peak plasma concentration levels were at least 100x higher that the levels occurring naturally with no accumulation seen with repeat dosing.
    • The company acquired the global rights to DUR-928 from the Department of Internal Medicine at Virginia Commonwealth University, VCU Medical Center and the McGuire VA Medical Center. It intends to proceed to Phase 2 development this year. A Phase 1 trial for an injectable version of DUR-928 should commence in H2.

  • SESN

    Eleven Bio's lead product candidate fails in Phase 3 study; shares plunge 78%

    • A Phase 3 trial, called OASIS, evaluating Eleven Biotherapeutics' (EBIO) lead product candidate, EBI-005, in patients with moderate-to-severe dry eye disease failed to achieve either of its co-primary endpoints of total corneal fluorescein staining score  and the patient-reported measurement related to ocular pain and discomfort compared to baseline at week 12.
    • There was no statistical difference between the EBI-005 cohort and the control group on the co-primary endpoints or any of the secondary endpoints. Both groups showed statistically significant improvements from baseline on the co-primaries while the change from baseline was higher in the control group than the EBI-005 group.
    • Considering the disappointing results, the company does not intend to proceed with a second Phase 3 in dry eye disease. It will continue its development of EBI-005 in allergic conjunctivitis, however.
    • The company will conduct a conference call this morning at 8:30 am ET to discuss the results.
    • EBI-005 is a recombinant protein that blocks (binds to) the interleukin-1 receptor, which plays a key role in inflammation.
    • Shares crater 78% premarket on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:46 AM | 3 Comments

  • Asian stocks diverge

    • Asian shares are mixed following weak U.S. industrial-production and consumer-confidence data on Friday, adding to fears that the economy is stuck in a bit of a rut.
    • Still, that's prompting speculation that the Fed will delay raising rates.
    • "The size of the decline in consumer confidence is pushing back estimates for a U.S. interest-rate hike to December," says equity strategist Shoji Hirakawa. "That’s beneficial for stock valuations."
    • Japanese shares end +0.8%, boosted by banks on positive dividend news.
    • Elsewhere, Hong Kong -1.1% after a strong session on Friday, China -0.2% and India +0.5%.
